trustfund:
TF092454-FOOD SUPPORT FOR VULNERABLE
            WOMEN AND CHILDREN

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Emergency Food Support
            for Vulnerable Women and Children Project for Liberia were
            as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: a number of
            lessons have emerged from implementing the project. A
            central lesson is that emergency projects with simple
            designs and straightforward objectives are highly likely to
            be implemented successfully. A strong commitment from
            government and partners, including the Bank, is also needed
            to prepare and implement emergency programs speedily and
            effectively. Fostering intersectoral linkages could enhance
            the prospects of achieving high levels of impact. Promoting
            concepts such as World Food Program (WFP's) Purchase
            for Progress (P4P) could help grow the agriculture sector,
            promote local purchases, and nurture a home-grown school
            feeding program. Because the effectiveness of interventions
            such as WFP's school feeding program, which involves
            bulk haulage of stock, depends on the quality of roads and
            bridges, linkages with future investments in rural
            infrastructure could have a significant, positive impact on
            WFP's activities.
